Thank you to the ladies for happily  agreeing to switch and to the employees that looked out for our comfort.

Wine selection was lovely and the ambiance felt lively without being too trendy. The only food available is cheese and the like, but they're a wine bar after all. There's are a few restaurants listed in their wine menu that they suggest people bring their take out from, which I thought was brilliant. I don't always like what wine bars have for snacks, and it's hard to impress without taking away from the wines. At least this way you're coming in with what you want and the pressure is on you for picking a good wine.
author: Jay V.

description:
I had pre-dinner drinks here with a friend.  It was a Monday night.  So, it was pretty slow.  The service was friendly and casual.  They have a pretty decent wine selection.  They also have a small but solid selection of beers in bottles.

It is a nice and cozy room.  It is a very small place.  I probably would not bring a larger group here.

Personally, I would also replace the hard wood seats at the high tops with something a little more comfortable.  I would not have been able to sit on them for a full evening of drinks.

Overall, I liked the place.  My companions liked it.  It was a good place for a pre-dinner drink.  I do not know what the vibe is like when it is busy.
author: Mark D.

description: Love this place.  Right in my neighborhood and have been coming here since they opened.  Jeff and Kamron are always welcoming.  Great wine selection and nice place to take a date.
author: Jason M.

description: Another gem in San Francisco. Never snobby, never under-dressed, this place is a perfect addition to any night or group size. I've been here twice now, and I've left very happy both times. Good wine. Good munchies. Good memories.
author: Cameron G.

description:
Had a wonderful after dinner late night drink. So romantic and perfect for some wine in an intimate setting.

The cheese plate was yummy too!
author: A D.

description:
SO cute! Stumbled upon this place by accident and sure glad I did! The ambiance is cozy- perfect for a date or catching up with a friend.   Actually, I was thinking it would even be perfect for an upscale bday gathering, except they don't serve food or hard liquor.   

More plus points, they have cozy couches and booths, fun music, and a diverse crowd.
author: Shree R.

description:
Have you ever been to a dry wedding reception?

I have.  And I do *not* recommend it to *anyone.*

You gotta just shrug your shoulders, tho; when two 19-year olds get married, and half the guests are underage, you can be sure that the reception is going to be serving cool glasses of... juice.  And foaming bottles of... Martinelli's sparkling cider.  Sodas.  Mineral water.  SIGH.

Needless to say, by the time Rachael J. and I got out of there we had a powerful thirst, and it wasn't for no damn mineral water.  Not unless it had Scotch in it.

The ceremony had been at Grace Cathedral and the reception in the Fairmont penthouse (yeah, and no booze--what a waste), so we were pretty close to Union Square, which, while it has many places to drink, is also chock-a-block with those tubby narwhales we all know as "tourists."

I hate drinking with tourists.

So, after a little consultation to determine what neighborhood would be appropriate for two nattily dressed people to go and get a little tipple on (i.e. "not the Mission"), we headed over to the Fillmore.

Neither of us knew that 'hood very well, so I SMS'ed a friend of mine: "yo, what's a good place to drink in the Fillmore?"

Just as we walked into The Wine Jar and were sitting down, my friend texted back:  "I don't drink in the Fillmore, there's nothing there but bourgeoise wine bars."

Ba da bing.

The Wine Jar had a sandwich board outside advertising 20% off bottles during happy hour, so in we went.

Honestly, despite being a wine bar (and thus, by definition, totally bourgeoise), The Wine Jar really struck a chord with me and Rachael J.  Mellow, low volume music, numerous places to sit, all with their own character and comfortable, and just generally relaxed--not snooty or "superior," as some of these places can be.

The 20% discount helped, and we found a nice red from Santa Barbara for $38 before the discount, tasty and a bottle of wine is a great way to knock back a few without having to get up and order anything else for a while.

All in all, it was a lovely stop.  Maybe a 100% markup on the wine, but like I said, the 20% discount took some of the pain out of the exchange; this would be a really nice date spot.  They even had a giant goblet full of chocolate candies (hello miniature Mr. Goodbar!).   If you ever need to find Martin W., I wouldn't recommend looking first in a wine bar, but if you should run into me in The Wine Jar, don't be surprised.
author: Martin W.

description:
I was directed here by the folks at SPQR as a good place to chill out while waiting for a table at SPQR. I didn't end up waiting at Wine Jar but went one Monday night after dinner at SPQR.

True, Monday nights aren't particularly busy but the place was very empty (only 2 other people there), and there was no music or any other ambient noise. It made for a slightly odd experience since I could hear every word uttered by the other patrons and waitstaff. My friend and I huddled in the seating area closest to the door (and furthest from everyone else in the bar) and talked in hushed voices - not because we had anything particularly secretive to share but that it was just an awkward and not terribly relaxing environment. Based on the other reviews I've read, I must have arrived near closing time since there was no music at all.

We just stayed for a glass of wine (they were closing early and had us leave by 10:30 or so). I found the by the glass menu to be relatively limited but decent enough for a quick catch up and the wait staff to be pleasant. This spot definitely seems like a better place to wait/hang out before continuing to your real destination rather than as a destination itself.
author: Wendy L.

description: Lesser known, great tasting wines and a fantastic bartender make this my go to wine bar in the city.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Perfect for private parties and wine tastings!! I went to a private party here for a friends 30th, and they did SUCH a great job at catering it.

An amazing spot, great location, decent prices, classy vibe, clean bathroom, and smiley, fun, wonderful owners. Beautifully decorated, with great photo exhibit hung in the back. 

They often have specials like "20% off bottles of wine happy hours" and "10% off to-go bottles".
author: Lauren S.

description: I don't come by this area often enough to be a regular, but I really enjoyed visiting this spot after taking in the Cherry Blossom Festival the previous weekend. The decor is dark, warm and cosy, there are plenty of seats for groups to hangout in their own clusters. The food and beverages are what you might expect from a wine bar. Wine Jar offers a nice tray selection of cheese, crackers, and olives. Nothing mind blowing. The waiter was really enthusiastic and he even was able to help me out with identifying a song I recognized playing in the background. I would definitely come back here if I was in the area.
author: Michael C.

description:
They were playing indie rock on a Sunday afternoon and no one batted an eye when I dramatically threw myself at the bar and ordered a bottle of cava all for myself. Seriously. This makes them 1) enablers, and 2) my new bffs. 

The bar is sleek but cozy, with a bar that seats a handful of people, some tables and couches spread around, and two tables outside. I had a lovely time drinking, munching on nuts and olives ($4), and chatting with the very sweet bar girl, who was knowledgeable about wine and pretended not to notice when I tripped on my way to the bathroom.

Thank goodness Heidi finally showed up to confirm that I am still a *closet* alcoholic (which means I only drink alone in the privacy of my own home. This is a perfect place to decompress post-mani/pedi or facial at one of the salons next door or to meet up with friends before or after a movie at the Kabuki. Tuesdays are $15 wine tasting nights and I can't wait!
author: Autumn K.

description: Small, dimly lit and cosy neighborhood wine and beer spot.
author: D K.

description:
Happy hour till 7 pm.
1 Blue Moon
1 Sunshine Wheat
1 Nuts and Olives Plate
+tax
=11 bucks!

I liked the beer comes with a nice icy glass.

It's a small bar has many sitting options, counter, out side tables, by the window, sofas in the middle, and 2 seating areas right by the wall.
Smart layout.
They must hire a good interior designer.
The bartender was nice too.

This is perfect place for us because we always go to Kabuki for a last bargain matinee and the movie ends about 4 pm. It is too early for dinner and don't want to have another coffee at the time, and Festa won't open til 7.

We had a nice and easy weekend late afternoon happy hour here and talked about the movie we just saw.
Bargain matinee and Happy hour.
Perfect.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Like the decor much more now than when they first opened.  The firs time I was here it was like the opened before they had time to get furniture.  
A great little wine bar with simple nibbles.
(thank you for getting rid of the fake flowers)
author: Jennifer D.

description: Interesting place. Not bad if all you want to do is sit with a friend and sip a glass of wine. But...if you would rather do this in a setting that does not include Top 40s type music (Beyonce's Single Ladies, anything by The Blackeyed Peas or Rhianna, etc.), I'd suggest you look elsewhere. I enjoy drinking wine in calmer settings, especially wine that is somewhat pricey when compared to retail prices by the bottle.
author: Erin W.

description: The wine was decent but the service was terrible.  On a date, I had finished two glasses of wine and then asked for a glass of water.  The female "bartender" immediately returned with the check and without the glass of water.  My date was thinking about getting another glass of wine but after such rude service we decided to spend our money elsewhere.  I won't be back.
author: Sara N.

description: Like this place a lot, they had a happy hour special 20% off bottles before 7 PM. That was pretty good. There was NO one in this place on Tuesday night, like dead. I wish they had more small bites to eat. Bruschetta boards, cheese and meats go perfectly with wine, so why dont all wine bars have them?
author: Jess O.

description:
one star for the fact that the place is cute and there was a decent amount of seating. no stars for the rude service we got.
when we got in, we were unsure of whether or not we opened the door and left it open or it was already open (it was freezing inside). my boyfriend went to close the door and a really rude bar tender immediately came and opened the door with a really nasty comment. if we didnt have friends coming to meet us we would have left immediately.
there are so many bars here, why would anyone but up with that type of attitude?
author: Erica D.

description:
Is there an option for half of a star? This place is horrible.

After reading a bunch of reviews we had expectations that this little spot would be a fun place to hang before going out to eat. Essentially, we spent $25 for two nice glasses of wine just to watch the owner oogle over blondes while completely ignoring other customers. There were ever several other couples who didn't wait the 15-20 minutes it took to get waited on. 

That's when it hit me. All of the 4-5 star reviews are from women. If you are a single woman looking to get chatted up by a wine bar owner, this is your place.

But if you are looking for a good glass of wine, good service, and a comfortable place to hang out... there are surely 20 other places on Fillmore Street worth your business. 

One little irony we saw was this place is called the "Wine Jar." They don't serve their wine out of jars... just typical wine glasses.

***Follow-up***
I received this message from the owner in response to this review. Now you get to see what we're talking about. 

Ironically, you are disrespectfully rating "me" rather than my business!!
So rude and immature of a person who is confidence and taste or lack there of is reflected in judging of others.  "Don't Judge me dude!  You don't know me!!  I don't know you and I don't care to know you. Your personal agenda, jealousy, sexual preferences are not my problems - I got enough personal problems on my own in my personal life and I don't care to know what you think about who I talk to or don't!!  

You have a nice stay in San Francisco!! And Don't ever come into my business again!

***
That's San Fransisco hospitality for you! Come to San Diego, where we know how to treat our tourists with respect.
author: Adam M.

description:
I liked this place.

We started the night intent on frolicking with the gays in castro (pride party night) but after 20 minutes of futile bumper to bumper craziness we gave up.  My gf suggested we grab a drink, and we head out driving mostly randomly on Filmore.  Last second decision (there was parking... woohoo!) so we ended up here.

Nice calm ambiance.  I'm goin out on a limb and calling this place "loungy".  You know the feel... darkened lighting, sexy sleek furniture and style.  I almost felt bad that her cousin was stuck with us... the place is perfect for a 1-1 date, maybe a bit to quiet and laid back for a larger group looking for fiesta-ing.

All in all? Great place to take a lady if you want to get laid (just keep your game tight come ON y'all!) but don't come here expecting a party.
author: Joseph F.

description:
I just adore places that are super casual and easy to hang out at. Seriously. Sit down, take a look at the menu, order at the bar or your table, and wait for a little bubbly or a bold red (or white if you must) wine.

The menu is easily to follow with giant headings sectioning reds from whites. They offer glass, half glass and of course bottle options. There's even a selection of beer for anti wine enthusiasts. 

It's a small spot where you can lounge on the sofas in the middle of the room, or sit up straight on the sleek bar stools. Two tables are set charmingly outside for warm weather. They also have a tempting cheese menu which I will have to try next time. 

Great happy hour: 20% off all bottles and $3 beers until 7pm...EVERYDAY! Friendly, unobtrusive service. Perfect before and (or) after dinner spot!
author: Theresa T.

description:
Love the space! It's cute, cozy, and they have a phenomenal wine selection. Specials during the week:

Mon: Industry nights - 25% of entire bill
Tues-Thurs: 4-7pm 20% off any bottle, $3 beers
Tues: Wine tasting special - 3 half glasses for $15

As for food, they have small bites/snacks like nuts, cheese, etc. Don't come here hungry...you might never leave because you're so buzzed. J.B. and I got this awesome Riesling so if you're into that, I def recommend it. I believe it was the one from Santa Barbara (they only have 2 and the one we got is listed second).
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Checked out Wine Jar recently to grab a last minute glass of wine, as it's in my neighborhood.

Cute and cozy atmosphere inside with some intimate seating options as well as bar seating. Decent selection of wines, including a good Malbec and Carmenere. Probably a bit overpriced, but pretty much in line with the neighborhood standards. I'd come back.
author: Lina L.

description:
Great, intimate wine bar in lower pac heights.

Wine selection decent, atmosphere unpretentious, nice neighborhoody place overall. Only one area for large groups... this is more of a trio or date place for a quiet low-key eve.  Last time we were here (a Weds) this older couple on a date (man in 50s, woman in 30s?) was totally making out at the bar all night. Amazing.

We got hungry and it was late so we ordered in a pizza from Extreme which paired nicely with our glasses of pinot. People kept eyeing up our pie and we probably could have charged $10/slice.
author: Shawn C.

description:
God it's been so long since I've written one of these.  Here we go...

Wine? I'm there! Recently my co-workers and I went out for a Friday after work wine binge and Wine Jar it was. This place is right in the Fillmore (who doesn't love this part of town?) So we get there at 4 pm (opening) and they are still closed....5 mins later....still close....10 mins goes by uummm still closed....wtf? So we leave...go down the street to another bar and call Wine Jar at about 4:20 and they are there! FINALLY. I'm thirsty.   

Anyways.......The place is super cute, cozy and comfortable. We order our first bottle (20% off? Hell yeah!) and some cheese. By the end of the night the 3 of us had 2 bottles of Cab and 1 bottle of Merlot. So HAPPY. 

I will return to the sweet Wine Jar for my wine fix.  If you do stop by try the Educated Guess it is a Cabernet, my favorite.
author: Jen N.

description:
I tried the Wine Jar for the first time last night. A friend and I were meeting others for dinner down the street, so pick it off of Yelp for a place to chill until our friends got into town. What a great choice it turned out to be. I loved it! Its a bit rustic and romantic, yet has some upscale flair to it. It's not a large place, and even thought there were quite of few people coming and going it never got crowded or too loud for conversation. 

We tried the evening's tasting of three wines which were very good. Prices are reasonable. Service was attentive. Its all good here. I'll"ll be back!  ...and there's great entertainment and dining choices within a few blocks!
author: Michelle G.

description:
Can I serve you some sexy?  Have a seat here.  And a glass of this.  Recline yourself, resign yourself, you're no match.

The interior is an earthy space with nooks and booths.  I'm reminded of a more hip, less touristy, more organic, less expensive XYZ.  What money can't buy you?

I came in here a while back with the BF.  We were trying to kill some time before the other sushi nazi at Kiss opened her door.  Inside, he got a glass of something red, I got a glass of something white.  I felt very grown up and sexy here.  But I was wearing jeans with possibly several holes in them.  

The service was very nice.  The clientele looked more precise than the W, but economic group.  Less of the groupie type, more of the quietly fabulous type.  A very nice looking woman in Lululemon.  Several deep, sensitive types with equally ephemeral girl-pals.  

I wish I could drink what they were drinking.
author: Christina C.

description:
I have been here twice, once on Tuesday when they have their wine tasting night and the second time was for a fundraiser we held here.  The tuesday wine tasting was okay, I don't think I was a fan of the particular tasting, the wines were not what I would have normally chosen for myself (mostly whites) so I'm guessing that the tasting night is probably hit or miss.  For the event, they were good as far as working with us and giving us an area and then donating a portion of the night's proceeds.  I felt that the service could have been better/friendlier/etc. so I was a little disappointed with that.  

This is not a place I would go out of my way to come to but I understand why it is a good spot for people who live in the neighborhood since I don't think Fillmore really has any other options for wine bars.
author: Selena G.

description:
waffling on my stars on this place...a few more things could put it over the top, but nonetheless its a pleasant find and addition to edge of Pac Heights/Japan Town.

Its definately a good date place to start with glass of wine. Space is small, tight, they have done a good job optimizing.

Service was fairly poor and snobby and we had to consistently flag down help rather than ever once be asked if we wanted anything.

Good wine selection by half glass and glass. One big big kudo - pours are very generous size, enough so its a differentiator. (hint, don't change it) Flights would be a nice addition, but in a place this size, I could see why they don't want the extra stemware to clean. I'd also like to see a few more  choices for simple food items, nibble, but again space maybe the primary issue.

An all around solid choice, and worth supporting!
author: William A.

description:
The owner comment below made me chuckle. You gotta love this tool called Yelp. I wish I could respond directly to her comment so I decided to update my review. Please see previous review and owner comment below. I guess my review hit a nerve and warranted a response. Thanks for "setting me straight" (putting me in my place so to speak) and gracing us with your time Jena. The audacity.... I do commend you on defending your staff, however your facts are not straight. Not only does Jena cry wolf, but she also makes false claims herself. First, if it was 11:15pm then why was it last call when the business hours are until midnight? It took us at least 10 minutes to get served so if he input our order after we ordered maybe it was a few minutes past 11pm, give or take it was still around 11pm when he informed us that we could only order 1 glass. 2nd, we were only given the option of having 1 glass so we both drank our glasses slow....even then I was still rushed out when I was asked to close the bill while my glass still had wine it. This was well before midnight because you confirm that the 3 other patrons at the bar were allowed to drink as long as they were out by midnight. Thanks for the confirmation. 3rd, if my review is riddled with falsehoods then why are there countless reviews from other yelpers that confirm my review of how rude your bartender is??? Do we all have it out for your bartender or is it a reflection of him??? Are you insinuating that we are all liars?
Laura, Lydia, Soph, Jane to name a few. Maybe it is a conspiracy theory. Just read below and the reviews speak for themselves. How many reviews will it take before it is addressed? What's the magic number? 4th, in an effort to undermine my review you blatantly state that I left a 75 cent tip (who's crying wolf now?) with nothing but malicious intent, suggesting that I needed it more than you do. Can you say - "shoot myself in the foot?" No wonder your staff has this attitude...it seems like it mimics the owners. I actually left $4 and some change for 2 glasses of wine at $24 (I paid cash dear so if there is a small tip from another customer's receipt then you obviously know why) even though the service warranted a ZERO tip. Tips are not automatic, they are earned...this is the nature of the beast of the service industry...come on you should know this already. 5th, I worked in the service industry during undergrad and I'm sorry Jena, your bartender is a prime example of how NOT to provide customer service. Your place lives and dies by its service...not just the products you offer. 6th, do not close the register when you still have customers inside the place and it is still during normal business hours, that is saved for after closing....hence the term closing. Lastly, with that egotistical and brazen attitude I'm surprised people come back to this place with so many other fine wine bars in the city. This is not a formula for success. Best of luck to you.
author: Anthony V.

description:
The cellar is now a curtained sitting area big enough for about 7 people. Nice.

A miscommunication between us and the server left us with a (delicious) $58 bottle we didn't originally want or order. Yes, after it was open. After mentioning the mix-up to the server, we got it for the $38 price we originally thought we were getting, which was a really good save.

Cheese plate ($14 for two kinds, with nuts and olives included) was a nice compliment for those of us who only had snacks and coffee all day.

They also looked for my lost gloves in the spot I was sitting (a simple effort not put forth by a surprising number of places), and found them with the tiniest bit of effort. Look at that.
author: Tara R.

description: place looks good, cheese and wine is good but the seating was uncomfortable =(
author: Tiff W.

description: Nothing ruins a good mood like bad service.  I really wanted to like this place but the manager/bartender who served us was terrible as he was rude, curt and completely useless. I'll just stick with Amelie the next time I want wine without sour grapes.
author: Soph H.

description:
HORRIBLY MANAGED!  I emailed them, as directed by their website, about having my little birthday get-together there.  I GOT NO FRIGGIN' RESPONSE!  

Then I called them up and asked if they'll be open to the public for the particular day.  The person on the phone said yes so I arranged for my friends to meet up there.  When I got there, THEY WERE F*CKING CLOSED!   EVEN THOUGH IT WAS STILL THEIR REGULAR BUSINESS HOURS!

In all fairness though, I will add that this particular day was July 3rd, during the Fillmore Street Jazz Fest.  So I reckon their not-being-open-even-though-they-said-they-would was related to the event.

We ended up going to Playground instead.
author: Arthur L.

description:
The signs on the wall telling customers to wear ear plugs (including a pack of plugs) if the music is too loud shows how the owner values his patrons. Guess this has been an issue...
Weird vibe, bordering on unfriendly.
author: Michelle G.

description:
I really enjoy this place - it's never over crowded, and its a good location to meet people for a night out on Filmore street. 

This is a real wine bar, not some of the contrived "wine bars" I've seen over the years. There's no "other liquor" here, no dinner menu, no pressure to drink or move along. The wines (the Wine Jar seems to have about 40+ at any given moment) are both California locals and imports. All of the wines (all of them) are available for by-the-glass or by-the-half-a-glass portions, as well as by the bottle. The sommeliers (I hesitate to call them bartenders) are knowledgeable, friendly and not obnoxious. If you like what you're drinking, they can arrange for you to buy a bottle or a case.

The only issue I have with the place is the speed of service. This is probably the east coaster in me talking, and I am sure that the relaxed atmosphere is something that they are trying to foster...but its a wee bit too relaxed. You can walk in and be the only person in the place, and it will take minutes before you are recognized as a customer. Likewise, once you are poured, your server might disappear for upwards of 20 minutes before you see them again.

It's a small price to pay, tho - just be prepared for it.
author: Rob D.

description:
As a nearby resident to this venue, I felt a sense of neighborhood loyalty to try this establishment. Friday evening at 5:00pm, I walked in with a girlfriend and asked the wine steward or whatever he calls himself to recommend a nice white. 

He poured me a flat wine obviously left over from the night prior that hadn't been properly vacuvined. Not wanting to be impolite, I asked for something more complex. 

His snarky response:
"your complex is to totally different than MY complex, what do you want?".

I chalked this up to somebody who doesn't know wine and should be slinging beers at a 49ers game, and I will take my business elsewhere.

No need for this behavior and attitude. 

I hope the owner reads this review.
author: vladimir p.

description: Stopped by on a Sunday night which happens to be acoustic night. Guitar + cello duet entertained with jazz covers and harmonious background tunes of their own. Ordered: Pinot Noir and an Artesian Cheese Plate consisting of Yellow Gouda, Manchago, and Queso Zamorano cheeses. Digged the vibe of this place which was both fitting when looking for a laid-back spot to unwind with friends close to home, or an intimate dimly-lit locale to mingle with a date!
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Just as I was complaining to my friend Sally that there aren't enough places to enjoy a drink on Fillmore Street, along comes a nice little surprise like Wine Jar. 

The place is a block or so north of the Kabuki, making it a swell spot to have a glass (or half bottle, or bottle) of wine before or after a film. Inside is cozy and I can see it getting almost too crowded at night. I'm guessing  the bar also morphs into a cougar/puma mating zone, so beware!

There are a couple of outdoor tables, and I believe there's a nice happy hour discount in the early evening. Fillmore Street is also one of the great avenues for people-watching, so I'd recommend stopping in on a weekend afternoon to witness passerbys stroll/strut on by. Stare at them -- laugh even -- you, my friend, have the nectar of the gods in hand and they do not.
author: Nish N.

description: I absolutely love this place!  I haven't been in a while and was so happy I decided to drop in this past weekend.  For me it's all about the atmosphere.  It's has a great lounge feel with an incredibly knowledgeable, friendly staff.  If I'm ever in the Fillmore area, for dinner or a movie, this is my go to place to get the night started on the right foot or cool down and relax at the end.
author: Owen W.

description:
It's attractive, sleek and stylish--real cozy.  I lean towards a more divey atmosphere, and being on the upper Fillmore stretch, it caters to the Pac Heights clientele, but it's tolerable during the week.  

Background music and incessant chatter make for a noisy environment, so it's not the greatest place for an intimate conversation.  But even with a bustling crowd, the cute server had a knack of keeping tabs on everyone, knowing just when to come around so you're not waiting too long for another glass or feeling rushed to finish your drink already in hand.  

I can't speak much towards the selection.  Though I've tended towards drinking wine over hard liquor this year, I am still just as clueless at deciphering the different types of wines and regions as I was before.  What I do know is what I like, and Wine Jar serves some tasty wine.  (Then again, I'm not hard to please on the alcohol front.)  In addition to their 1/2 glass, glass, and bottle offerings, they also serve a number of beers.  Food wise, there are cheese plates to help tide you over.

Bottom line, it's a choice spot to unwind after work for a drink or two with friends before heading elsewhere.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I think the bar itself is adorable, love the bar, couches, and the music in there.  This is basically to the wonderful bartender.  When you fill out a job application to a wine bar, I would assume you would research a little bit about wine.  When we asked her what she thought about the zins, her response was "I just started." Period.  Then she walked away. Wtf? I've had better recommendations from the free sample guy at Costco. 50 bucks for 2 glasses of wine and a piece of cheese.
author: Sara L.

description:
I came here by myself and liked it. I spoke to the bartender who was very cool in dispensing a drink of wine. He let me try three and then got a Riesling. 
For my experience here, they have a lovely lay out about the place, a super clean bathroom and bartenders who make good company as I get buzzed on one glass of wine. I'd drink more, but I'm a 'cheap date.'
I enjoyed myself and my ten dollar glass of wine. They had a wine room that is pretty to look at but can only be opened by the wine god. 
I appreciate it when new businesses seed. I hope this seed grows and grows. 
My only request would be have Guinness and Red Tail Ale on hand. I like them more than Chimay. Yeah, I'm wierd, kooky, so what?
Beer and wine are served, bitches.
author: J A.

description:
Yeah, a wine list with descriptions!  Not as extensive as Amelie's list, but I could order without having to pin a waiter down and ask 20 questions.  The space was a little dark, which I suppose is good if you want to make out in public with your date, but I was seated (with a date) in an awkwardly large area that 3 people joined us (and politely asked permission) in to make it far from romantic.  I think that space would work better with an after work crew.  

They do not do flights apparently, which is a little sad, since I am an amateur and like flights to introduce me to new things and to compare without needing to drink a full glass of something that could be nasty (they do have 1/2 glasses).
author: Cara J.

description:
My curse is that every time I decide to move, something appears in my soon-to-be-ex neighborhood which I've really, really wanted.  So I knew (I KNEW) a wine bar would magically appear within walking distance as soon as I decided to leave Pac Heights.

And I was right, dammit.

From the outside the Wine Jar doesn't necessarily look promising - it is quite dark! - but inside they've done a great job creating intimacy out of what is essentially a strip mall space.  Comfortable seating with several spaces for groups to congregate, well-chosen colors and low lighting make it classy and cozy.  

While they don't have an overly extensive wine list, the two relatively large groups I came here with never ran out of things we liked.  I did have to go ask about some of the selections, but once I did the advice was cheerfully given and perfect.  The one thing the list doesn't seem overly conducive to is flights.  They offer half-glasses of everything, but I couldn't quite put together a cohesive flight from the options available.

Honestly, I liked the vibe here enough to want to make this a regular drinks spot.  Unfortunately, I will soon be several miles, one bridge and another city away.  Hmph.
author: Suzanne B.

description: adorable little place with a decent selection. Perfect for happy hour (20% off a bottle) and nice little appetizers, try a cheese plate can't go wrong with manchego and comes with trader joe rice crackers, mix of olives and nuts-- yum. Definitely not pretentious. You need to work a little to get service, but good ambiance, clean bathroom, and nice vibe.
author: Naomi K.

description: An earth-toned candlelit spot with plenty of comfortable seats, several stellar choices of wine by the glass, and solid service, this is the type of place to talk with friends before or after dinner, and the type of place you wish for during those more human times when you're too sedate to pose at the Redwood Room but too hedonistic to rely, hopelessly, on a typical restaurant bar.
author: Patrick B.

description:
I would love to give this place 1/2 a star, but I know everyone has to make a living, so I'll stick with 1.

Don't go here peckish after 10:00 PM because as our server told us, 'At 10:00 PM, the kitchen closes.'  Kitchen?  By 'kitchen' I'm guessing they mean refrigerator because all they serve is cheese.  By this logic, they won't serve you cheese past 10:00 PM.  Even if you walk in at 10:05, which is exactly what my friend and I did after a movie, thirsty for vino and hungry for, of all things, cheese.

How hard can it be to slice manchego?  Obviously hard enough not to reopen that kitchen, er, fridge five minutes past the time it closes.

There's a lot of places that pour wine, including Florio down the block who is more than willing to break out the cheese slicer a few minutes after they close their kitchen (what looks like a real kitchen, for all practical purposes).  Let's move on.
author: Laura P.

description:
Great little swanky wine bar.  Small place, decorated in dark, chique colors - complete with a nice bar for tasting.  The feel of the place is really relaxing and the music was jazzy and yet electronic - great ambience. They also had some beautiful photography on the walls, helping the overall feel. Certaintly would be a great place for a date, esp. in the evening.

My friends came in for the beers though, sadly nothing on tap.  I have a blue moon, fine from a bottle.  Nice serving glasses though.  We also ordered a cheese plate - the cheese was ok, instead of crackers they had wafers (eh) but the olives and nuts were tasty and fresh.  Good amount of food for the price.

The service was excellent, attentive, friendly and spot on.
author: Sabrina A.

description: Really cute wine bar.  Got there around 8 pm and shared a private booth with 3 friends.   We shared two bottles of wine (the Bedrock 2006 Syrah and the Siete Fincas 2009 Malbec).  Both fantastic.  Great music playing in the background but not so loud we couldn't talk to each other. Fun night out with the ladies.
author: Kristal D.

description:
Wine Jar, I dig your style! Modern and classy, brown accents, earth tones, nice wine room, window seating, cozy and comfy. Wines are served by the glass, half glass, or bottle. A great new establishment on Fillmore. 
Damn, I used to live on Fillmore/Pine when all there was to do was go to Harrys (ugh!) and now, you lovely Wine Jar, you came too late.
author: Amy J.

description:
I chose it for friday happy hour - i like it! 

It  is the place for nice glass of wine without an expensive tag attached. I enjoyed a yum cab (try the educated guess if it's on your list) on a loungy couch. My girl Anju loved her chardonnay. The cheese plate was very nice, included tasty olives.  But it was a drag to have flat bland crackers with that great manchego - so i am hoping something different might be added into the rotation.

It is an ideal stopover to fillmore local venues....we ran into friends who dropped in as they waited for their spot to come up at at spqr. And I headed to Kabuki theater around 9:30.  

I am in agreement with the fellow yelper about the unnecessary flat screen - I love my basketball, but having the glare of the game in the corner does throw off what is otherwise a great modern deco vibe.  

Cameron was attentive. It seemed to me that he enjoyed running the place and liked connecting into his patrons. It's a casual and solid fillmore haunt.
author: Shanta J.

description:
One thing this city is definitely not lacking is wine bars (except in my neighborhood...hm, business idea)....however, I digress.  There are a plethora of wine bars in ALMOST every area of the city.  It seems to be the new "it" business; from District to South to Amelie...there are certainly a number of places you can go to enjoy a good glass of wine.

That being said, Wine Jar is a perfect addition to the swanky Pac Heights/Fillmore neighborhood.  It's decor is un-fussed - small, yet doesn't have the feeling of being cramped.  Several tables for small groups spread throughout the room as well as a bar.  Muted tones and low light set the mood for a date or a relaxing evening with a few friends.  The bartenders seem friendly and check on you often (without being overbearing) and the crowd seems to be local late 20's/early 30's.

I briefly looked at the wine selection and saw they had a Zinfandel so went with that.  I was pleased with my choice, even if it was a bit pricey ($16).  One nice thing they offer is a half glass which is great if you actually want to taste more than a couple wines.  One star off for no Australia wines tho (that's for you, Jerk-ass ;-) ).  

If I can read into my future, I will likely be here again...well, maybe it's b/c one of my best friends lives down the street....but I really enjoyed the cozy atmosphere this place has.  I hope it does well!
author: Melanie N.

description: Very nice ambience and friendly staff ...my fav. neighborhood  bar even though I live far from there
author: M S.

description:
4.5

Sometimes, I go places and wonder, What would I have done if this were my bar/restaurant/store? Wine Jar is one of those places that hits so close to how I'd do it.

From perfect lighting to an amazing wine list with apt descriptions to good music and great services, this place really rocks it. The prices weren't too bad, either.

We grabbed a drink here while waiting for a table at nearby SPQR, and it served as just the right prescription. I had a glass of Jeriko Pinor Noir ($10) that was among the best Pinots I've ever had; Tara had the sparkling rosé, and it was fruity and delicious.

The place wasn't too crowded on a Tuesday night. Maybe that's because it was Tuesday. Maybe it's because it was two days before Thanksgiving. Either way, it was just right, all around.
author: Jeff H.

description: An alright place to chug some wine.  And chug I did because #1, I was already half-drunk when I arrived, #2 the decently-priced wines/champers on the menu were not so great and #3 it was so dark in there I was lucky not to have inadvertently tried to drink out of a candle or something.  I saw a few people drinking beers while sitting on a couch.  Beer?  In a fancy Fillmore wine bar?  Pick one!!  When I'm on the wine train I like my merlot with a side of pinot and I hate being distracted by beer that seems like a much better deal than a whole bottle of wine.
author: Holly B.

description:
This is a pretty much ideal first date meeting point and has a great selection of wines.

It's quite a small, one room bar but makes good use of space and doesn't seem too crowded. It's all dark wood which gives it a romantic air and the stools are at least comfortable and there's a sofa and easy chairs too. But if you're in a large group I'd go somewhere with a little more room.

The wine selection is excellent and comes in at around $8-15 a glass or $35+ for a bottle. It also does cheese, cracker and olive plates for $8+, depending on how many cheeses you want.

Downsides: One unisex toilet for the whole place could lead to queuing when it's busy and there's either no air conditioning or it's about as effective as a lace condom, so they crack open the windows. That's fine if you're in the middle or back but a tad draughty if you're at the front of the place.
author: Iain T.

description:
NO Stars. A wine bar with scant selection, tons of attitude from the staff, no 1/2 glasses or tastes. I was there with 2 friends and 4 couples walked in and walked out during the time we were there. 
I'd recommend going up to D&M, buying a bottle and drinking out of a paper bag sitting at a bus stop before I'd go back here. 

I'm just shocked they are still around in this economy.
author: Frank P.

description:
Hmmm... I guess I liked this place and I guess I would go back again if I was in the neighborhood shopping or at the cinema and was in need of a drink (ha - am I ever not in need of a drink?). It was not exactly what you would call edgy or full of character - but it nice enough... I guess.

It was all nice enough. It has a nice (clever) name. The bar was nicely decorated. The Pac Heights people in there seemed quite nice (not at all like the boisterous crowd I passed by as I walked past the Fillmore). The music was quite nice (if you like Coldplay and... wait - was that The The... or Paul Simon... it could have been). And the bar staff were also quite nice, I guess (though not at all chatty and downright pissed when I asked for one of the three beers that they were apparently out of).

The Chimay I had was nice enough. I guess.
author: Kingpin X.

description: Have been back to Wine Bar several times since my not so great experience.  Better experience.  Nice neighborhood wine bar, decent wine list, better attention to detail.  Nice cheese selection to compliment wines.  Only downside - need a little more help at times as there's only one person.
author: Deanna D.

description:
Well, it *was* a soft opening so I won't slam it too much...

It is nice that I now have a wine bar within walking distance. And they have a really, really fabulous menu of obscure and amazing mostly-California wines. A handful of imports, but the strength is in the domestic juice like T-Vines Zinfandel and Zapaltas Syrah. The interior is the now-standard warm brown floors, walls, ceiling (okay, I'm getting a little tired with this BROWN thing in this city -- there ARE other colors with which to decorate!) but comfy settees and low-to-the-ground leather chairs were inviting enough. And the mix of 80s New Wave and Moby music was a tad too loud for comfortable conversation; not a bad mix, just a bit too much.

The main detraction? There are only two cheeses currently available on the menu and each one is $9.00 (I'd like a selection and perhaps multiple cheeses on one plate, please). And sorry, whatever the two cheeses were, they were pretty forgetful. I have to believe that Saturday was their first day as it took almost 15 minutes to get those cheese plates and when they arrived, one could only assume the cheese (and mushy olives) had been stored in the freezer. It took several additional minutes before the cheeses were at an edible temperature. And Saltine crackers? Puleeze...

We chatted with one of the guys working there who indicated he was a consultant (versus an owner, I assume) and he agreed that there are some things which need tweaking. We talked about the great quality of their wine list as well as the need to fix the cheese course. They seemed to get a lot of business on Saturday; we were one of the first parties in and the bar was quickly filling up.

But one other point of contention which I noticed; one of the servers behind the bar was pouring a glass for a customer and needed to open a second bottle to complete the pour; the server did NOT check the newly opened bottle for cork taint before adding it to the partially-poured glass. For a wine bar, this is a major indiscretion. With the exception of two plates of cheese, there is only one product being served and it better damn well be good. Not checking for flaws before service is a big faux pas.

Of course I'll go back and hopefully become a regular. But I also hope they see these notes...
author: Carolyn T.

description:
Don't know how I missed this on Fillmore the past year or so. Well, I'm a FAN now!

Met the owner, Cameron last week, and hung out in the "nook" - a quiet little cabana tucked away to the side.   Drank an incredible Malbec and nibbled on their exquisite cheese plate.   

Been back twice already and I am converting friends by the minute.
author: Jessie S.

description: It's got a fun wine list and a really cute interior.  I stopped here for about thirty minutes for two half-glasses of wine.  I'd stop by again if they didn't blast Moby through the speakers.  Seriously, people, it's not 1997.
author: Bill H.

description:
Not as good as the first two times I went there. They appear to moving towards the "wine for bros" model with really loud circa 1992 music being pumped throughout the bar. Great for a place like BarNone, not so much a place like Wine Jar.

Wine list is still decent, but I like to drink my wine in peace, not with Eddie Vedder.
author: Chris B.

description: unattentive & discriminatory - wine was cool, nice place, good environmental vibes but did not feel welcomed. other people in my party felt the same way. never going back
author: Edward S.

description: It's exactly what Fillmore needed.  A low-key, relaxed, unpretentious little gem with a charming, friendly owner, who offers a decent wine selection.  I like that they give you the half-glass option so you can try a good variety w/o over-doing it.  Get on their mailing list - they do a special event every Tuesday.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Was in the type of melancholy that only a Malbec could solve. Headed up the street with the I-Tunes gods cursing me with an Everything but the Girl track. Hit the FF thinking how the fudge did that get in there?"...in time to   hear the phone ring. "I'm in this cute little wine bar on Fillmore...gotta check it out?" The Wiley Coyote smoke cloud puff was behind me faster than you can say "Beep Beep!" 

Sex-hay, low-key interior, fab wine list and small plates will cure any woe. Great place for date starter before moving on to any main courses!
author: Johnny C.

description:
Nice little setup. I remember when Wine Jar first opened this summer...the walls were bare and neighborhood patrons strolled in curious about their new potential hang out. 

Now I'm glad to see that business is steady because I really enjoy their diversified wine and cheese lists.

Service is a laid back atmosphere. Not a nightlife destination spot but stop by during happy hour. Kameron and Jess are super nice and will chat you up with all the wine knowledge you need.
author: Charlene A.

description: Cool spot. Good wine list by the glass. Good spot for a drink before or after a movie at the kabuki theater.
author: David B.

description: I have been coming to this place for years and finally felt compelled to share the overwhelmingly positive experience I have had any time I want to enjoy a glass of wine with friends. The loungey atmosphere rivals my living room with more colorful residents and better paletes. Every time I come here I am greeted with smiles and pleasant conversation. The wine list features selections that are not readily available and the service is great. If you are interested in an unpretentious, yet quality evening, Wine Jar is your place.
author: Kristin G.

description:
Super cute little wine bar.  I love that there are sofas, stools and even semi-enclosed booth that can probably accommodate 4-6 people comfortably.

Nice selections, and good service.  Love the lighting...because you know, at least I look decent in the dark!

I'd definitely come back.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Definitely a cool little spot in the hood. They have a nice selection of wines and sparkling wines. I opted for one of the sparkling wine offerings, and it was delicious for only $7. Their glasses range from about that to $12. The bartender was chill, and very attentive to our little booth. We always had a beverage in hand. We came on a very slow/empty night, but I'm pretty sure I've seen this place packed on many occasions.
author: Ashley D.

description:
I wanted to like Wine Jar more...really, I did.  I love Pacific Heights, and I love wine bars, but Wine Jar fell short of my expectations.  It was a warm Friday evening, and the tables were full, so my companion and I opt to sit at the bar.  Neither server at the bar greeted us,until I greet them (and at that time we've looked at the menu and were ready to order).  

The venue itself wasn't anything spectacular--walls were a tan color lined with black and white framed photographs and simple furniture.  Has the feel of a neighborhood spot, which is probably what they were aiming for.

Wine lists were extensive enough with lots of options by the glass, 1/2 bottles and full bottles (a few even 1/2 glass).  I opted for a nice pinot noir that I'd probably order again, as did my companion.  

Again, I wanted to like Wine Jar more than I did.  I think I'll give it another try and sit at one of the tables and have a more leisurely time.
author: Marie B.

description:
5am-6pm working, baking, working, selling,  working, baking...

7pm after a long hot shower enjoying delicious pizza at Delfina 

8:30pm-10pm  3 glasses of very tasty Sauvignon Blanc at Wine Jar with a bunch of good friends, taking the edge of the crazy busy day

10:30pm fall into bed...a tinyyy bit on the tipsy side 

11pm - 5am dream about the cute & charming wine jar where we had a blast
author: Doro P.

description:
I was starting to wonder when somebody was going to notice the lack of a wine bar in the Pacific Heights area.

The Wine Jar is a great little place.  They haven't been open very long and they are still getting their "groove" but so far, so good.

The wine list is short (although it's starting to expand) but smart, and they offer by the bottle, the glass or even a half-glass.  The staff is knowledgeable and their love for wine shows.

For food, so far they only offer a cheese plate which is decent.   If you get really hungry Pizza Inferno is practically next door.  SPQR is across the street, but you could die of starvation waiting for a table there.

They have a few different beers for your friends who don't like wine for some strange reason.

Like I said, so far so good, it will be awesome to watch this place grow.  Get there now before the crowds find out about it and it becomes impossible to get a seat.
author: Mark G.

description:
I finally went to the Wine Jar a few weeks after it opened earlier this year.  I've been back twice.  It's a great addition to this part of Fillmore Street, because I don't have to walk up the hill (kidding, I'm not that lazy).  The scene can be a little odd, the owner (?) seems to do a lot of partying (heavy drinking) with the patrons.  I've also seen it closed a couple weekend nights for private parties (boooo).  The staff is knowledgeable and the selection is good.  

The photo on Yelp is deceiving.  Unless it's broad daylight, the place is dark, like super dim to pitch black.

DO NOT READ if you have a weak stomach: The first night I went in, I was so excited, because they had a few cheeses to taste.  When I got my plate, I noticed one looked like it had been left out too long (it was a manchego), but I thought to myself, this is a professional establishment, all is well.  I puked my brains out all night and couldn't even go to work the next day.

Overall, a good place to stop for a drink before or after dinner on Fillmore.  I've seen some strange promotion signs there lately, so I don't know if they are doing well or not, things like "half price bottles for take out."  Are you a wine bar or a discount corner store?
author: Wendy N.

description: What cute, upscale yet cozy place for happy hour and to catch up with friends!  My co-workers and I organized a quick happy hour here.  Its a great place for a large group because were are plenty of nooks with seats so that you can actually see everyone.  A couple of friends and I shared the 2008 pinot grigio from sonoma and it was definitely delightful, fresh and crisp!  Definitely plan on coming here again! :)
author: Janice M.

description:
Don't think I can add much to the reviews, but I DID like this place very much.  Everything was casual, the food bites ample and tasty.  The selection good and inexpensive.  

I really liked the crowd:  not too trendy or agey for my tastes.  In the immortal words of our Governator:  I'll be back!

~ Ms. Alisa
author: A W.

description: Great spot to have a glass of wine with a date or a girlfriend. Its quiet, nice conversation spot with a good selection of small bites. Stop by here for quickie before a movie at the Sundance.
author: Tara M.

description:
I do love this place. First, it's long overdue that a Wine Bar situates itself on Fillmore street....especially after a nice meal at Jackson Fillmore, La Med, or Fresca. This place is exactly what I have wanted. A nice, cozy place, not overrun with pretentious people, rather small groups just looking to chill and chat over a glass of Bordeaux. 

The place has a great dark lounge-esque ambiance. The wine selection is pretty good, and the people working there are really friendly. But let me explain to you exactly why I gave it 5 stars...

So a group of us is sitting there, enjoying a glass of red wine from the Alsace region, and chit chatting about life. Apparently someone told a joke because my friend sitting next to me laughs really hard and slams her glass down thinking she's drinking beer or something. The stem of the glass breaks and somehow all the wine gets all over my shirt.  In a split second, one of the bartenders yanks me by the hand and take me outside, only to start spraying this Wine-away spray all over me. "It works great....just wash it when you go home and it'll all be gone". I look like a moron with my arms spread out while some dude is spraying stuff all over me. But lo and behold, the next morning when I took the shirt out of the dryer, it was CLEAN! Amazing. It worked.....and I owe it all to the bartender!!! Thank you Mr. Bartender, if you're reading this review. You da man!

I'm definitely going back...hopefully without getting wine spilled all over me. But then again, even if it DOES, I know I'm safe!
author: Samir P.

description:
This is a great little place to tuck into after dinner. 

Even though it is a wine bar, I really wanted another beer after my salt-tastrophe at Woodside Fish Co. and this place looked cozy and inviting. 

The interior is dark and lush and there's plenty of room for people. 

The sound level is low and you can hear your dining companion talking to you.

There is only one bathroom, which is bad for a wine bar. But there is a cozy seat and a mirror outside the bathroom.

The bartender is friendly and efficient.

I wouldnt' make a trip to go here but if you're in the hood and looking for a place to stop in and chat and wrap up the evening, or even stay for a quiet night, then I'd definitely stop in here.
author: Andrea S.

description:
It's the decor that bugged me.  There's no personality, no community, nothing special, just dark stained wood and pottery barn leather.  Total cookie-cutter-

However, the small wine list is solid.  The pac heights crowd is pretty and laid back.  -and drinking good wine and appreciating women are probably my two favorite things to do in the world so...
author: Jake H.

description:
I'd come back if in the neighborhood and looking for a glass of wine.

Pros: 

Friendly bartender. I asked a question about the style of a particular wine, and he answered honestly - and ended up pointing me to something he thought I might like more - I approved.

Nice space. Everyone can essentially see everyone/the whole room, but there are distinct seating areas for group of 2-8 that allow each group to feel like they have their own area/experience.

You can order in from a bunch of local restaurants.

The neutrals:

Not a bad $4 olive and almond selection. 

Wine selection is fine but not exceptional.

Cons:

A cheese list that needs to try way harder.

No menus from said local restaurants.
author: r g.

description:
Another new fav bar of mine!  One that I found accidentally after a Monday movie nite at the Kabuki on the way to grab a drink at ... uh, dare I say it ... Harry's Bar (of all places, and as opposite to the Wine Jar as it gets)...   Thank gawd we came across the Wine Jar on our way and followed the inviting hunch that took over and guided us into this little (yeah, it's small) treasure of a place where you can simply be and enjoy.

Fantastic wine selection, the overwhelming part of it being taken care of by Kamran, the owner, who was very helpful and right on the spot with his recommendation.  Very pleasant atmosphere, friendly and attentive service.  Not on my "regular route," though, but I'd definitely pick this place when hanging out in the area, as in after a Fillmore concert.  Seems to be a good date spot, too.
author: Sabine W.

description:
The wine bar can have a great niche in a restaurant heaven like the City.  When you're waiting for a table at the latest hot spot that doesn't take reservations (read SPQR) you can go grab a glass of wine and a plate of cheese, like me and the S.O. did on Friday night at WIne Jar.  

The place is smaller, but has a nice couch area for your group, and decent space at the bar for those so inclined to ogle the wait staff.  It can get crowded quickly, but we hit a nice pause at about 8PM, a little late for the after-work crowd, and a little early for the night-lifers.  

I had the Argentinian blend, which was quite good, and she had the Syrah, with no complaints.  We ordered a plate of Manchego, which comes with crackers, nuts, and olives.  The crackers reminded me of ice cream cones, the cake kind, but not sweet.  The nuts were salty, and sadly no napkins were forthcoming.  

It was a bit loud with all the carousing of the group at the couches and the Radiohead on the speakers.  Wouldn't have an intimate conversation here, but it is lively.

Overall, this place serves its purpose well.  It meets a gap in the wine bar scene in the Fillmore, and offers a place to wait until SPQR has a table.  Two parties that were at Wine Jar were seated right after us.
author: Greg K.

description: It's a good place to meet before a Kabuki movie. They have a couch if you need to snuggle. It's cozy. The happy hour deal is a bonus. They have a pretty good beer selection. The bartender has a pac. heights disposition so don't expect charm, particularly if you are female (that's fine with me; give me my drink and go away). There is a TV in there, unless I was hallucinating.
author: E. R.

description:
This is one of the more pleasant wine bars in the pac heights/russian hill/marina area. It doesn't look like much on the outside, but it's pleasant inside -- with a good volume level for the music and friendly service.

As for the wine, they have a good selection. Not necessarily wines you've heard of -- but good wines nonetheless. The last time we went into the bar we had a long conversation with the owner about the bar, his professional past, his future goals, etc. Very pleasant. He even showed us some inventions he's patenting (we're sworn to secrecy though!). 

All in all, a fun place to get a glass of wine. What more do you want?
author: Jason P.

description: Cute, cozy, close to home.  I had a yummy Malbec here for $10/glass...and then my friend found it on wine.com for $9.79/bottle.  Not that I was really surprised, necessarily, but now I try to go during happy hour.
author: Allison D.

description: cute tiny wine bar on fillmore.  nothing special. but if you aren't ready to end the night and you have been drinking wine all night...head to wine jar...and get comfy with your date on their cute little couches.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
I am a fan of wine jar. It's very cute and quaint inside. They have a large variety of wines, and even have a jar of Hershey kisses for your chocolate cravings. 

A group of us went in after dinner, and we were able to snag 6 seats at the bar after people left, around 10pm. By the time we left, it was packed and pumping.

I would definitely come back here again!
author: Jeanne C.

description: I love this place.  It's my go-to neighborhood watering hole (and a high-end one at that).  The wine is always good, their snack options are tasty and the atmosphere is comfy and welcoming.  The only problem is that you find it hard to leave once you've relaxed into their booths and had a few glasses of wine.  I couldn't bring myself to give it five stars because of the almost-too-high prices, but it's worth it once you settle into the overstuffed couches.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Well dang.

The bartender may be smokin (a little Matthew McCaunoughey, and little Will Schuster) but he sure as hell is R-U-D-E. Here are the things that annoyed me about my last visit to this spot:

1. Embarrassing trying to order from Out the Door off a stained, out of date menu (hey, I was two glasses in and didn't see the date - but it's July, people. Why was there a March menu even out?)

2. When I finally did order something from a current menu, I asked the bartender, "Hey, do you pick it up or do they deliver?" (OBVIOUSLY i meant do I pick it up, not you bartender), to which he replies, "NO, YOU do." Wow. So, so rude. 

3. Bartender gives us the evil eye alllllllllll night (until he came to drop off the bill, at which point he kinda tried to re-form his scowl into a sort of half-smile thing). 

I knew he had been extremely nasty to my friend a few weeks before - I thought maybe he was having a bad night. Turns out there is a more permanent stick up his a**. 

Honestly, I don't like Fillmore street anyway, so I will definitely NOT be returning. Sounds like the folks who wrote the other reviews here for the most part agree.
author: Lia I.

description:
What a great place to visit on a weekday night. The decor is inviting, the wine list is long, and the owner is welcoming and gracious. We had such a good time here, and it's well worth the trip if you don't live in the neighborhood. 

I'm excited for you and the awesome date you're going to have here one day.
author: Jill C.

description:
Oh Wine Jar, you've been a wonderful new friend.

It's not just that the first time I visited you was with my good friend from New Zealand who works in the wine industry, and pronounces her name "Jar".  It's more than that, deeper.  First off, the lovely outdoor seating benches/windowsills, where one can drink wine, eat cheese, and smoke a ciggie, if one is inclined.  Also, the selection of wine is wonderful, fantastic, and has not disappointed.  Ever.  And the cheese platter.  Such a wonderful delight of tastes and sensations, complimented by the best little thin cracker/wafer/heavenly bits known to man.  Wine Jar is my new best friend 2008.  I can't wait to continue the relationship into 2009!
author: Ria D.

description: I went to the Wine Jar last night for probably about the 3rd tme, and have officially decided that it's my new favorite neighborhood wine bar :)  They have a fantastic selection of wines, a knowledgeable staff that gives great suggestions and very reasonable prices.  We unknowingly went in during their happy hour last night and got a fantastic bottle of Malbec for 20% off.  The atomosphere is great too....very cozy if you're on a date, but also cute tables/bar seating if you're just popping in with a friend.  This is a great place to stop in for a pre or post dinner glass (or bottle, if you're like me ;-) of wine....two thumbs up for the Wine Jar.
author: Liz L.

description: This place is in a great location and the concept is great -a dimly lit, romantic wine bar for couples to cuddle. That said, I was a bit disappointed by Wine Jar and after thinking about it, I have to say it came down to our server... He didn't check in on us and when we needed him, it was difficult to get his attention. He seemed put-out by our request to clear some sticky substance from the surface of the table and when he came to address the issue he didn't even clean it because he had one cocktail napkin soaked in water and rubbed it around one spot then walked away. So really, the place isn't bad but we had back luck on a Wednesday night with a grouchy server.
author: Eliz M.

description:
I went to Sausalito a couple of weekends ago and headed to a little joint called Bacchus and Venus for a tasting ... the girl working the tasting raved about and suggested the Wine Jar on Fillmore ... so I have been looking forward to giving it a try.

Totally new to the city and missing my favorite places in DC, I was excited to try this place.  

Miss Sausalito was so right!  Had an EXCELLENT night here.  The wine list was short and sweet.  I told the owner what I wanted and he poured the perfect glass.  Beyond the wine itself, the owner was a riot and chatted with my friend and I on and off throughout the night.  The crowd in general was laid back and unpretentious (which is sometimes hard to come by with the wino crowd).

I can't wait to go back ... and will probably try a tasting there soon.

***Update***

Went to Wine Jar last night ... the first time was no fluke, this is a great little wine bar.  Selection and service are perfect.
author: Cara M.

description:
Whoa!  Started this review about 2 weeks ago and never quite got around to finishing it...

My bf and I were trying to figure out what to do on a Saturday night.  We nixed plans for a comedy club and instead embarked on an urban adventure to find a wine bar in the city.  We drove by a place he knew of in Union Square and it looks barren, so we continued on our search.  We remembered the Wine Jar, which we had just passed by the day before when we were in the area trying to kill some time before a movie at the Kabuki theatres.

The staff there was extremely friendly and let us taste 3 different red wines (a combination of Zins and a Shiraz) before we decided to get a bottle of the Balletto Zinfandel.  We made an attempt to sit outside but that was thwarted when we were at a table that was downwind from a couple of hearty smokers, so we ventured back inside and bellied up to the bar and spent the next hour or so bantering and polishing off that bottle.  By that point, we were happily buzzed and content that our mission was accomplished.
author: Evelyn K.

description: I like this place.  Cozy little wine bar with a loungy atmosphere on Fillmore, away from the hustle and bustle of Fillmore.  I've enjoyed every wine I've tried here, but that's not saying much, since I've met few wines I don't like.  Overall, a good first date spot, or a good spot to catch up with a friend.  I only wish it were a bit closer to my place; I always seem to run late when I'm walking over there.
author: Danielle B.

description:
This is one of my favorite little places on Fillmore to grab a glass of wine.

It's small, comfortable and casual, with a limited but tasty selection of wines. There aren't too many separate places to sit (a couple couches, a couple small/tucked away tables, one tall table, the bar) but it's cozy and has a great ambiance. They also have a really nice feature where you can order food from one of 5 nearby restaurants and eat it at Wine Jar with your wine. Overall a great place for a chill, low-key, welcoming glass or three of wine.
author: Hilary M.

description:
Had a great experience here.  They have a tasting every Tuesday for $15, which usually involves 3 or 4 wines from their normal menu.  

The guy running the tasting (maybe the owner) was a really nice guy.  Very personable, friendly, and knew his wines.  

Worth stopping by with a few friends, and a great place to relax for a few minutes and catch up with them before heading down to the Kabuki Cinemas or to dinner.  Surprised this place isn't more crowded.
author: Andy C.

description: This place was really nice on the inside.  I  liked their positive messages posted up throughout and I can imagine how cozy it would be on a dark overcast day.   The wine was served at the right temperature and the beer had a good foamy head on it. I had intended to email the establishment first before posting this but they do not have email on their website so here is my review.  My boyfriend and I went yesterday to have drinks after reading several favorable reviews. I was very disappointed.  The one thing that would have made this place a 5 star was the service. The bartender demonstrated the height of unprofessional behaviour.  He was the only staff person there and besides us & his friend at the bar, there was only one other party that was getting ready to leave.  We received no greeting or acknowledgement when we arrived, he didn't come over to take our order until we initiated getting up ourselves to place the order.  He talked loudly with the person sitting at the bar and divulged all sorts of information, dishing on friends, talking about the screenplay he was writing, talking about his roommate situation, it just went on.  He and his friend were eating at the bar and dropping f*&k bombs every few sentences. We decided to order a cheese plate and have another drink, even though I was ready to leave, my boyfriend didn't want to search out another place.  Again, we got up to place our order and only then did he come by.  Later another couple walked in and I watched the same poor service play out.  No greeting, no walk to the table until they started to get up to do so themselves.   If the bartender was the manager as mentioned in another post, perhaps there is no hope for this place and it will be hit and miss as long as he is serviing.  I wished I had a better review to post.
author: Ciel S.

description: Oh how I miss Wine Jar. I used to live (and work) about 2 blocks from here until my roots in SD came calling.  Wine Jar is more than just you're neighborhood winering hole.  Walking in, I always had this feeling as though I'd stepped on a magic carpet and was whisked away to a sexy, but polished room. Complete with an ever adventurous wine list and delectable morsels to appreciate every sip, Cameron is careful to research and change the menu frequently in an effort to broaden everyone's palate. The air of mystique is gently coupled with an intimate atmosphere and most gracious staff. In fact, I'll never forget my 28th birthday when I walked in with about 12 close friends and Cameron greeted us with sparkling Prosseco to fete my day. I guess I'm nostalgic for that special place where everybody knows your name, but in a really classy way  ;)
author: Susan C.

description:
Fillmore was lacking a decent wine bar.  While a number of restaurants offer good wine lists and bar space (SPQR, Elite Cafe), often times they are so crowded it's impossible to get in or you feel pressure to order an entire meal.  The Wine Jar fills the gap by providing a neat space and good wine selection.  

Prices are average for the neighborhood and selection of wine by the glass is decent (but not as extensive as some like SNOB or Amelie on Polk).  Most of the seating is stools at the counter, which is more comfortable than you might expect.  The service was very attentive and the pours were generous - I also thought the atmosphere was great for a quiet chat.  

The space is fairly small, which means it feels lively with relatively few people and could quickly get jammed as it becomes more popular.  I hope they add a curtain or something around the door before fall because you can imagine it getting chilly every time someone opens the door.  

Overall, worth checking out if you live nearby and want something a little more sophisticated than Long Bar or the Grove for a glass of wine.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Such an excellent thing to have a charming wine bar in my neighborhood!  Very cute spot with a comfortable vibe.  Decent wine list, and while they don't offer tastes or flights (which, IMHO wine bars really should do) the half glasses are reasonably priced and on the evening we were there, we generous pours.

Service is basic; we found that although we were seated, going to the bar was the best way to get anything ordered.    Of the four wines we tried, I would happily enjoy one again.  The other three did not live up to their descriptions.  Bold wines should be bold.
author: Danielle R.

description:
Great wines at fair prices.  Wine Jar put together a fantastic tasting for only $15.  It was a lineup of five similarly "heavy" wines.... but they were so expressive they didn't muttle together.  Here was the lineup:

Grenache Blanc
Syrah
Syrah
Chateauneuf-du-Pape
Some Grenache blend I don't remember

This lineup was HUGE, all big wines.  Had them with the cheese platter and they more than held their ground.

As for service, the owner is very friendly, and the waitress easily put up with the 15 or so people we brought in all at once (after a previous screening of Bottle Shock).  She handled several tabs and made sure that I was only charged for what I ordered.  I will return soon.
author: Nate H.

description:
Pretty nice addition to the area.  This is where Trio Cafe used to be.  Kind of sad to see that place go.  (But, if I really cared that much, I would have actually patronized it.)

It's not a large space, but it makes good use of what it's got.  Likewise for their wine list.  It's got a nice wide range of a few good wines.  A little heavier on the whites than most (meaning that it's about balanced).  Hit or miss with some of them, but maybe that's just my taste.

I'm glad there's a wine bar right around the corner from me, so I'll be trying back to see how this place progresses.
author: masa s.

description: Very rude bartender.  Bad vibe and bad customer service for a so-so wine selection.  Won't be going back.   Too many other good spots in the hood to put up with bad service . . . .  plus, who ever heard of TVs in a wine bar?  No thanks.
author: Selina C.

description:
Walking down Fillmore with my BF and stumbled upon Wine Jar. We thought it was incredibly cute, so we figured we would sit and have a bottle of wine on a nice Sunday afternoon.

The wine was good, the service was great. Had a blast sitting outside and people watching!

Art
author: Art A.

description:
I would say this cute new wine bar gets a 3.5 but since that was not an option, I am giving it a 4. Hoping perhaps they will get there... I think its great to have a cute wine bar on this part of Fillmore. Harry's just doesn't cut it for wine... Wine Jar is very cute, cozy, neigborhood style place where you can go and meet a friend for a drink and can actually hear them talk.  

I had the cheese plate, but they were out of the best one which is the Manchego...it was only like 730pm so I was a little disappointed. Thank goodness the olives that came with it made up for it.  

I think they need to add a few more items to the appetizer list.  The wine I tasted was quite good but I would like to see a larger selection considering it is a wine bar!  Maybe they could add some 'flights' which is always nice when tasting different wines. 

The service was good, not great. Sorta mellow like the place. 

Overall, great new addition to the area, just needs a little improvement~
author: Wendi K.

description: Surprisingly cozy for a wine bar that I have walked by several times and it looked too dark from the outside so I never went it...until last night.  I was wonderful! Friendly service, good wine list, healthy pour, great music at the right amount of loudness to allow for privacy AND comfortable conversation.  I really like this place and am so happy to have a neighborhood spot that is close to my house and a great place to hang out.
author: Nilu r.

description: I'm compelled to write this review because of the unbelievably hostile service my friend and I received from the employee on Tuesday evening.  I hope the owner reads this and takes note.  It was 6:30pm on Tuesday, Oct. 11.  There was only one employee running the show - he was the bartender as well as the server.  That was fine, as it was a quiet weekday evening.  My friend and I sat in a "booth" on one side and were excited to catch up after not seeing each other for months.  After about 10 minutes the employee approached us, and rather than cracking anything resembling a smile or saying "hi, how are you" or ANY such thing, he gave us a hostile glare and said "do you know what you want yet?!"  We were shocked by his tone, especially given that WE WERE IN A WINE BAR.  Presumably, a place that should have a pleasant atmosphere and make people feel welcome.  We responded, "we haven't had a chance to look at the menu, yet."  He grabbed the menus from the side of the table and threw them onto our table.  Literally.  We looked at the list and decided what we wanted.  Another 10 minutes later, he approached again -- same hostile glare -- and asked "do you KNOW yet??"  We each ordered a glass of wine.  Before we could order cheese, he had hurried away.  When he brought our wine, I said "we also wanted to order some cheese."  His response: "WHAT KIND."  I looked at my friend in utter disbelief, that this employee was literally attacking us while we were customers of the bar.  If I ever decide to give Wine Jar another chance, I will literally check who is working there, and if it's this guy, I will leave.
author: Molly P.

description:
Been back a few times and have found that the owner and employees are much friendlier how I found them to be through my first impression (a bad night, perhaps?)

Anyway, my impressions have been much more favorable, and the fact that the owner contacted me regarding my less than stellar review leads me to believe that he cares about the place and it's rep.

So, in short (too late right?) I'm a fan... and as much as I like the music selection, I think you could diversify it a little
author: Adam and Lela M.

description:
